Created an attachment (id=5708)
Patch.

Current implementation swallowed the exception, giving no feedback at all. The
problem was that SelectionConverter.getElementAtOffset returned a wrong
JavaElement, since there are no JavaElements for local types.

The patch uses SelectionConverter.codeResolve, which allows to reject the
refacoring on invalid selections.
Markus, i think this patch is for something else

Created an attachment (id=5735)
Patch

Sorry, here's the right one.

this is in conflict with bug 32896

Dirk, what do we do here?
I suggest we detect such cases and issue an error dialog that these methods 
cannot be moved

To stay consistent move should use the eclosing element. 

Short term action:
- use enclosing element, but make sure that the example doesn't throw an
  exception.

long term action:
- on run we should build a partial AST and pass it around so that the 
  refactorings don't rely on IJavaElement which don't exist for local
  types.

Sorry for the confusion.

Created an attachment (id=5791)
Patch no.2 (short term action)

Takes the enclosing JavaElement and informs the user if refactoring not
applicable. In the example, Foo#createGUI is chosen, since jcore still has no
JavaElements for local types.

I think bug 32896 shouldn't apply to the "Move Method" refactoring.

When I select a method name in a MethodInvocation, I expect the *selection* to
be the target of the refactoring action (and not the enclosing element).

What we should do is the following:
- If the selection resolves (via SelectionConverter.codeResolve) to a valid
refactoring target, then use it.
- Otherwise, look for an enclosing element which would be a valid target.

The problem with methods in local classes is +/- orthogonal to the above
problem. Perhaps, we'd better wait until JavaElements are available for local
types and then consistently deal with the problem in all refactorings.

Patch released. Fixed in I-build > 20030901.

Long term solution should be "use AST" or "Java core has elements for local 
types". Both action require a path over most of the refactorings and should 
therefore not be covered by this PR.

Markus, please comment.

The exception looks the same but has a different cause.

Now, there are JavaElements for anonymous types (and their methods, ...). Our
refactorings currently don't check whether the selection is inside an anonymous
type and have undefined behaviour on anonymous types.

We should disable most (all?) refactorings on anonymous types and display a
proper error message. Not for M4.

We must also consider local types (named types inside method bodies). They cause
trouble as well.

Created an attachment (id=6426)
Patch 3

- replace the offending ad-hoc name guessing to use
NamingConventions.suggestArgumentNames(.)

- disable MoveInstanceMethodRefactoring for methods in local types
-> in that case, ReorgMove is used as a fallback, which is consistent with
other illegal moves (e.g. moving a constructor, ...)
